comments:
The plugin that I'm working on (org.sangam.plugin) references a server whose 
code is in another plugin (org.syncshare.server). However, when I launch the 
runtime workbench, I start getting NoClassDefFoundError - even though 
plugin.xml has a requires clause importing org.syncshare.server. I am wondering 
if I'm doing something wrong in M7, as this seems to be fairly basic 
functionality that should work fine.

I am attaching plugin.xml.

If you wish to duplicate the problem, try getting the following two projects:
Repository: cvs.sourceforge.net
CVSROOT: /cvsroot/sangam
Modules: org.sangam.plugin, org.syncshare.server

Then, launch the Run-time Workbench. In the workbench, make a file association 
for .java files in the preference page, to open the Sangam Editor. Then, open 
any java file. The editor (org.sangam.editor.SangamEditor) refuses to open and 
in the errog log, I see:

Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.core.runtime".

Does your plugin.xml for your server plugin have an export clause.

The plugin did have an export clause.  The xml ran as follows:

<runtime>
 <library name="server.jar">
   <export name="*" />
 </library>
</runtime>

We found that the issue was resolved when we removed the META-INF directory 
that we had in the imported plugin.

So, the problem can be restated as follows.  There's this plugin B that depends 
on plugin A which has a META-INF directory.  B is unable to access any of the 
classes in A even though the import statements were correct in B's plugin.xml 
and the export statements were correct in A's plugin.xml.  When the META-INF 
directory is deleted, everything works fine and B can access classes in A.

I wonder why this happens.

Platform:  Win2000 Server, Eclipse 3.0 M7.  The problem is JRE independent.

Since M6, the Manifest.mf file is used to capture runtime information.
However you should not have to delete it.
Please try with your original manifest and with M8.
Reopen against equinox / general is this still occurs in recent builds.
